channel.title: Forkbomb
channel.description:
So... I was reading about 'fork' on wikipedia and came across '[url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fork_bomb]fork bombs[/url]', and an example for bash:
[code]:(){ :|:& };:[/code]
[code] :() # define ':' -- whenever we say ':', do this: { # beginning of what to do when we say ':' : # load another copy of the ':' function into memory... | # ...and pipe its output to... : # ...another copy of ':' function, which has to be loaded into memory # (therefore, ':|:' simply gets two copies of ':' loaded whenever ':' is called) & # disown the functions -- if the first ':' is killed, # all of the functions that it has started should NOT be auto-killed } # end of what to do when we say ':' ; # Having defined ':', we should now... : # ...call ':', initiating a chain-reaction: each ':' will start two more.[/code]
I ssh'd over to my university's CS server and ran it to see what would happen.
It crashed my connection, and any attempts to reconnect have been timing out.
Could this be enough to crash the entire server?

item.title: Forkbomb
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Daginith, post:36, topic:436894”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=539608.msg3956067#msg3956067 date=1332769288]
Good job copying from Wikipedia, Daginith.
[/quote]
The second one, i did, yes =D I could never come up with something like that.

the first one, someone taught me at school a while back, but never called it a ‘forkbomb’ we’d just crash computers with it.[/quote]
they obviously need an auto restarter and they’re set

Read full topic

item.title: Forkbomb
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:33, topic:436894”][quote author=Daginith link=topic=539608.msg3955530#msg3955530 date=1332713944]

you have to kill all of them, not just the “original” one
unless youre exceedingly quick and can somehow catch the time between one dying and another one forking

Yeah i know, the most simple version of it on windows is

:die
Start /max
goto die

Loads new terminals and Crashes the computer within a few min.

I know with this one each process dosen’t have sub processes. My point is even this one, opening 20+ windows a second is very hard to stop.
[/quote]This isn’t moparscape. That’s not a forkbomb.[/quote]
I am well aware that this isn’t moperscape, although i dont see how thats relevant…

I suppose a better example on windows would be:

Linux Style: 

:(){
 :|:&
};:

Read full topic

item.title: Forkbomb
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

zachera:

Could you even “soft” `reboot’ if you forkbomb a system? Lol.

If you are able to kill the forkbomb process, otherwise, no.

Read full topic

item.title: Forkbomb
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:27, topic:436894”][quote author=t4 link=topic=539608.msg3953913#msg3953913 date=1332557319]

^ though top/ps if you can actually run it by the time you get to the machine ofc
also http://grsecurity.net/

it’s doubtful - there’s a limit to the amount of processes that can be ran on most linux boxes so most of the time you won’t be able to fire off a command within a few moments of the fork’s permutation.
[/quote]

which is exactly what i meant by “if you can run it” and “set proper ulimits” :P[/quote]
ah, ok

[quote=“zachera, post:26, topic:436894”][quote author=t4 link=topic=539608.msg3953913#msg3953913 date=1332557319]

^ though top/ps if you can actually run it by the time you get to the machine ofc
also http://grsecurity.net/

it’s doubtful - there’s a limit to the amount of processes that can be ran on most linux boxes so most of the time you won’t be able to fire off a command within a few moments of the fork’s permutation.
[/quote][quote author=t4 link=topic=539608.msg3953761#msg3953761 date=1332544357]

its also retardedly easy to see who did it
[/quote]`top’?

looking through bash_history or logs of the like

looking through = nano',vi’, `vim’, etc

I wonder if it’s quicker to run nano' orvi’ vs. top'/ps’ …

[/quote]
except for you can look at the logs after reboot - don’t forget more/less/cat/grep

Read full topic

item.title: Forkbomb
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Unless you run a command with nohup, screen, or something similar, ssh kills it when you disconnect, so I would guess that something like that happened, eventually it was killed and the resources freed.

you can close a session and still have applications running.

Read full topic

item.title: Forkbomb
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

the system is usually long dead by then if you dont have decent ulimits

max file handles and max process ceilings get hit long before cpu or ram is a problem

Read full topic

item.title: Forkbomb
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

I doubt it, even killall doesnt kill a fork bomb usually

It can after a certain period of time though, right? (when the CPU gives a little time to the ‘killall’ application)

Read full topic

item.title: Forkbomb
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=".Unlimited, post:14, topic:436894"][quote author=Mopman link=topic=539608.msg3951173#msg3951173 date=1332291118]
he has a point though, who doesnt have proper ulimits on a shared box like that

since they didnt, they probably dont have the ability to catch you either, dw about it
[/quote]
Or they do this on purpose to catch kids such as OP.[/quote]My highschool did that. They left a vulnerability in a networked “teaching” drive (turns out the only thing on it was a bunch of OLD books in txt form), and anyone who accessed it lost network access for the remainder of their time attending any school in our board.

Read full topic
